review.title: Using Signals to Improve Automatic Classification of Temporal Relations
review.abstract: Temporal information conveyed by language describes how the world around us changes through time. Events, durations and times are all temporal elements that can be viewed as intervals. These intervals are sometimes temporally related in text. Automatically determining the nature of such relations is a complex and unsolved problem. Some words can act as "signals" which suggest a temporal ordering between intervals. In this paper, we use these signal words to improve the accuracy of a recent approach to classification of temporal links.

metadata.title: Using Signals to Improve Automatic Classification of Temporal Relations

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Effective automation of tasks such as summarizing and answering questions requires methods of information extraction that can interpret information about the time stored in documents. A difficult problem with time information extraction is the arrangement of events. Although the exact arrangement of events has been the subject of much research [1, 10, 5, 8], work with the temporal signals present in the text - for example, phrases such as afterward, for the duration, and during - is limited and often yields only minimal benefit [11]. These words clearly contain temporal arrangement information that human readers can access. This paper examines the augmentation of a current, powerful time link classifier with information about time signals. Our hypothesis is that signals provide information useful for TLINK classification.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: At this point, we will present the notes used in this paper, present problems with temporal signals, and discuss some of the relevant literature.

sections.heading: 2.1 Temporal Annotation
sections.text: A sophisticated annotation scheme is required to capture temporal information well: we use the TimeML scheme [12], which contains tags for annotating events and time expressions (< EVENT > and < TIMEX3 >, respectively) and temporal relationships between intervals (< TLINK >) and signal expressions (< SIGNAL >); the two largest resources of TimeML-annotated text are TimeBank [13] and the AQUAINT TimeML corpus1, which we merge into a corpus for this work.

sections.heading: 2.2 Temporal Links
sections.text: Temporal links (orTLINKs) describe a temporal relationship between two intervals, each of which is either an event or a time expression. Allen [2] describes a number of relationship types related to the interval endpoints. As our work is based on data commented on by TimeML, we use a set of TimeML relationships similar to Allen's. Each temporal link can optionally refer to a signal.

sections.heading: 2.3 Signals
sections.text: Signals in TimeML are used to indicate multiple events (time quantification) and also to indicate words indicating the nature of the relationship between two intervals. We are only interested in this latter use of signals for the order of events. "A University Grammar of English" [14] lists a subset of these words in Section 10.5, "Time Relaters." For example, in the sentence John smiled after he ate, the word specifies an order of events. This example could be represented in TimeML as follows: John < EVENT id = "e1" > smiling < / EVENT > < SIGNAL id = "s1" > after < / SIGNAL > he < EVENT id = "e2" > ate < / EVENT > Signal is a signal indicating such a signal. < TLINK id = "l1" eventID = TolatrelatEvent = "> TAFTER = TAFNAL =" is not the signal. "

sections.heading: 2.4 Previous work
sections.text: In the temporal order of events, it is intuitively likely that signal information can be useful. In previous automated TLINK classification work, the trend was not to use signals directly as the primary source for ordering information, although other attributes of commented TLINKs and EVENTs were used as training features. For example, the most popular automatic TimeML annotation tool (TARSQI [15]) operates without SIGNAL annotation. Lapata and Lascarides [7] worked with signals and used a limited reference list of signal tokens instead of extracting signal text from human annotated data. This work related only to concurrent temporal associations. Their accuracy in classifying time relations was 70.7%. Bethard and Martin [3] included some characteristics that described signals, with the full-word function (the signal text) being the eighth most important in their characteristics for classifying time.

sections.heading: 3 Method
sections.text: To explore whether signal information can be successfully used for the TLINK classification, we proceed as follows: First, we implement a well-known TLINK relation classifier with state-of-the-art accuracy; then we add various signal-related characteristics to the classifier to investigate their impact on classification performance; the approach we replicated as accurately as possible was taken from Mani et al. [9] In short, the method was as follows. First, the set of possible relationship types was reduced by applying a mapping; second, the following information from each TLINK is used as characteristics: event class, aspect modality, voltage, event sequence, event sequence in any relation to a previous relationship; this simplifies the training data and provides more examples per time relationship class; and second, the following information from each TLINK is used as characteristics: event class, aspect modality, tension, event sequence, event sequence of events, event sequence for each event, and whether we have the same event, as well as two Boolean characteristics, both of which indicate the same event, third aspect.

sections.text: To add information about signals to our training instances, we use the additional features described below; the two arguments of a TLINK are represented by e1 and e2 - signal phrase. This shows the actual text marked as SIGNAL. From this, we can begin to guess temporal orders based on signal phrases. However, the mere use of the expression is insufficient. For example, the two sentences Run before sleep and Before sleep, run can be equivalent in time, as they both specify two events in the order run-sleep that were previously signaled by the same word. - Textual order of e1 / e2. The textual order of linked events can be reversed without affecting the temporal order. Therefore, it is important to know the textual order of events and their signals, even if we know a temporal order. This feature assumes that the order event-signal-text event-value occurs most frequently in either e1 or e2.

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: When switching to a feature set that adds SIGNAL information, including signal event word order / distance data, you achieve a predictive accuracy of 61.46%. The increase is small compared to an accuracy of 60.32% without this information, but TLINKs that use a SIGNAL in are a minority in our corpus (possibly due to subcomments).It would be interesting to see the performance difference if you only classify TLINKs that use a SIGNAL. In total, there are 11783 TLINKs in the combined corpus, of which 7.6% are listed including a SIGNAL; for TimeBank v1.2, the value is higher at 11.2% (see Table 2).The percentage of signaled TLINKs in our data is the lowest at 5.1%.The results of extending the feature set through a split of signaled and unsignaled links are shown in Table 5, from a third / two thirds rating / training split.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: This suggests that signals are useful when it comes to providing information for classifying temporal links, and that the features we have used to describe them are effective. Future work will focus on improving signal and TLINK annotation. We need to explore how we can differentiate whether or not a string is used as a temporal signal in the text. Next, after finding a temporal signal, we need to determine which intervals it connects in time. Finally, we can try to comment on a temporal link based on the signal.
